title: 107_s780
content: The "Neighbor to Neighbor Act" allows individuals who do not itemize deductions to deduct a portion of their charitable contributions. The "Neighbor to Neighbor Act" allows individuals who do not itemize deductions to deduct charitable contributions directly under section 63 of the Internal Revenue Code. The deduction is limited to the amount specified for the taxable year. The "Neighbor to Neighbor Act" allows individuals to deduct charitable contributions directly under section 63 of the Internal Revenue Code, specifically through the direct charitable deduction. This deduction is limited to the amount specified for the taxable year. The "Neighbor to Neighbor Act" allows individuals to deduct charitable contributions directly under section 63 of the Internal Revenue Code, specifically through the direct charitable deduction. Contributions are deemed paid on the last day of the taxable year. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 3 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a charitable deduction exception to the overall limitation on itemized deductions. SEC. 4 repeals the special limitation on contributions of capital gain property. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2000. SEC. 4 repeals the special limitation on contributions of capital gain property. The changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2000. Amendments to section 170(b) of the Internal Revenue Code involve striking and redesignating certain subparagraphs. Conforming amendments are made to section 170(e)(5) regarding the definition of 'capital gain property'. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 5 amends provisions in the Internal Revenue Code to extend the carryover period for excess contributions from 5 to 10 years. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 6 allows tax-free distributions from individual retirement accounts for charitable purposes. SEC. 6 allows tax-free distributions from individual retirement accounts for charitable purposes to qualified organizations described in section 170(c) of the Internal Revenue Code. Individual retirement account distributions can be made to charitable remainder annuity trusts, charitable remainder unitrusts, pooled income funds, or for charitable gift annuities, as long as no person other than the account holder benefits from the distribution. Individual retirement account distributions can be made to charitable trusts or organizations described in section 170(c), with the amount distributed treated as income for tax purposes. The text discusses qualified charitable distributions from individual retirement accounts to charitable trusts or organizations, with specific criteria outlined for exclusion from gross income. The text discusses qualified charitable distributions from individual retirement accounts to charitable trusts or organizations, with specific criteria outlined for exclusion from gross income for individuals aged 59 1/2 and above. The deduction under section 170 for the taxpayer in the taxable year is reduced by the sum of qualified charitable distributions that would otherwise be included in the taxpayer's gross income. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. Repeal of excise tax on net investment income of tax-exempt foundations.
